posts.name:
Sue Deagle
Sue Deagle
posts.content:
Is it just me, or are people more and more trying to fit the mold of "perfect human being?" It's not enough to be perfect at our jobs, we have to have perfect routines, coping methods, ways of being...


“Do you still use a paper boarding pass???”

My daughter asked me this recently, incredulous. And yes, I do. Because deep down, I like to be over-prepared. Call it my risk manager’s instinct.

We all have quirks — habits, preferences, personality ticks that don’t always make sense but help us feel in control. The problem isn’t having them; it’s fighting them.

When we resist our quirks, they turn into sources of shame or defensiveness. When we embrace them, they lose their power and let us focus on what really matters.

For me, that means accepting my harmless habits (like paper boarding passes) while addressing the quirks with real impact — like rushing through big decisions or getting defensive under stress.

The lesson? Not every imperfection needs fixing.

Focus on the ones that truly affect your performance, your relationships, or your well-being. And let the rest go.



(And a goofy selfie just to drive the point home.)

comments.commentText: You can read my full post on this topic here! https://theluminist.substack.com/p/111-why-im-totally-fine-with-my-nonsensical

posts.name:
Alamin Hossain
Alamin Hossain
posts.content:
Copy and paste these ChatGPT prompts to learn anything 10X faster!

You may want to save this.


1. Teach through storytelling

"Craft a short, engaging story that explains [concept] in a way that makes it memorable and easy to recall."


2. Create a cheat sheet

"Generate a concise cheat sheet or one-pager summarizing the most critical aspects of [topic/skill] for quick reference."


3. Build connections between topics

"Explain how [Topic A] and [Topic B] are connected, and how understanding their relationship can deepen my knowledge of both."


4. Design active practice exercises

"Suggest 3 practical exercises or challenges I can do to apply [skill/topic] in real-life scenarios and reinforce learning."


5. Prioritize learning focus

"Identify the 3 most crucial subtopics within [topic] that I should focus on first for maximum learning efficiency."


6. Quiz for retention

"Create a 5-question quiz about [topic] to test my understanding and identify any gaps in my knowledge."


7. Simplify complex ideas

"Break down [complex topic] into its simplest form, using analogies or examples from everyday life to make it instantly understandable."


8. Create a learning roadmap

"Design a 30-day learning plan for mastering [skill/topic], including daily objectives, recommended resources, and measurable milestones."


9. Highlight key insights

"Summarize the top 5 takeaways from [topic/book/course], focusing on actionable insights that I can immediately apply."


10. Decode industry jargon

"Translate the jargon and technical terms in [field/topic] into plain, easy-to-understand language without losing meaning."


-----

posts.name:
Ranveer Allahbadia
Ranveer Allahbadia
posts.content:
I’ve grown as a content creator.
I’ve grown as a person.
And I’m still growing.

I’m not chasing anyone else.
I’m not here to compete with anyone.
Not their wins, not their timelines, not their applause.

The global fame, the recognition, the milestones—they’re all part of the journey.

But they aren’t the goal.
The real goal is the responsibility I carry every single day.

Every podcast is a promise.
A promise to deliver knowledge, to inspire, and to impact lives.

People trust me to bring stories that matter.
That trust fuels everything I do.

It’s not about chasing numbers or recognition.
It’s about serving others through meaningful conversations.

At the end of the day, it’s not me versus the world.
It’s me versus me.

At the core of it all, it’s about purpose.
To grow, to serve, and to leave something meaningful behind.

Gratitude To ALL

comments.commentText: Wow, what an inspiring post!  I guess we can say you're not just growing, you're glow-ing"!  Keep shining and spreading those good vibes. Remember, even trees take time to grow, and they don’t worry about the tree next to them.  Keep up the amazing work and keep those podcasts coming! ️

Serving through meaningful conversations is the truest success. Growth with purpose always wins. 
Keep inspiring and impacting lives Ranveer

posts.name:
Jean Marie DiGiovanna
Jean Marie DiGiovanna
posts.content:
If you're asking your team members, "What can I do to help?" there's a more powerful question to ask that leads to results rapidly.


Instead, ask this question...

"What's the one thing, if it were in place, would help you move forward?"

When you're specific in our ask (e.g. "one thing", "one step", "one task", "one way") it triggers the mind to go find that thing.

When you stay general in your questions..."How can I help?" or "What do you need?" it's too vague for the mind to want to go look for the answer. In fact, it can cause the mind to go into overwhelm.

Next time you're helping your team member work through a challenge, try asking a more specific question and notice what happens.

And, do let me know how it goes!

**For more powerful questions to ask your team, check out my new Linkedin Learning Program, "Powerful Questions Every Leader Should Ask their Team to Enhance Communication." Link in comments or in the Library.

comments.commentText: For more powerful questions to ask, check out my new LinkedIn Learning course here: https://www.linkedin.com/learning/powerful-questions-every-leader-should-ask-to-enhance-team-communication?trk=share_android_course_learning&shareId=JyVYSu0GSPO9t6vgxgTrHg%3D%3D

posts.name:
Daniel Dzikowski
Daniel Dzikowski
posts.content:
Stress: The Silent Thief of Your Peace and Potential. Stress doesn’t just steal your energy; it robs you of your ability to truly thrive.  

Letting go is the key to stopping stress from taking over.

Many sacrifice too much in the name of success:
Chronic stress leaves you drained, unable to enjoy life.

Anxiety clouds your focus, making it hard to stay present.

You feel stuck in a loop of overwork and burnout.

Your health declines, yet you keep pushing through.

But here’s the truth: You don’t have to live like this.

Letting go creates space for balance and clarity:

1. Drop what no longer serves you—unhelpful thoughts, habits, or expectations.
2. Build daily practices that naturally reduce stress and release tension.
3. Prioritise your health by tuning in to your emotions and needs.
4. Redefine success as a life where peace, joy, and progress coexist.

 If you found this post helpful, repost it with your network.

Followfor proven strategies to protect your health, reduce stress, and reclaim your freedom.

comments.commentText:
Stress really does act like a silent thief, and we often don’t realize it until it’s too late. 

Letting go isn’t just about reducing stress. 

It’s about reclaiming the life we deserve—one filled with balance, purpose, and joy.

Thanks for this empowering message.
So correct Howard. You can utilise letting go in so many different ways. My current favourite is clearing my resistance to things that I 'should' or 'must' do.
To me, true wealth is living with love ...
I agree. Trying to see all people and situations from the eyes of love is incredibly powerful.

posts.name:
Archana Manjrekar
Archana Manjrekar
posts.content:
A Sunday spent spreading smiles and hope. ️

Today, I had the privilege of spending my Sunday with the incredible kids we serve as part of the Robin Hood Army — a zero-funds volunteer organization dedicated to redistributing surplus food to the less fortunate.

Their smiles, energy, and boundless hope are a heartwarming reminder that small acts of kindness can spark a ripple effect of change. Moments like these show the power of coming together as a community to create a real, lasting impact.

A heartfelt shoutout to Neel Ghose, the visionary founder of the Robin Hood Army, the incredibleTeam, and partners like, who are amplifying this mission with their support. Together, we’re proving that creating change doesn’t require millions - it just takes intent and effort.

Let’s all do our part, however small, to make the world a better place. 

PS: For those who aren’t familiar with this incredible movement, I highly encourage you to check out these links to learn more about the amazing work Robin Hood Army does and how they’re creating waves of goodness across the globe:

comments.commentText: Archana, your experience with the Robin Hood Army beautifully illustrates how even small contributions can lead to significant change. It’s truly inspiring to see individuals like you who not only recognize the power of community but also actively engage in uplifting those around us. Thank you for leading by example and reminding us all of the impact we can have when we come together.
That is such a thoughtful message! Thank you

Wonderful Human centred initiative Archana Manjrekar

All the Best !

posts.name:
Shawn Nason
Shawn Nason
posts.content:
𝗦𝘁𝗼𝗽 𝗠𝗮𝗻𝗮𝗴𝗶𝗻𝗴, 𝗦𝘁𝗮𝗿𝘁 𝗟𝗼𝘃𝗶𝗻𝗴

Here’s a trend most won’t talk about: 𝗟𝗼𝘃𝗲 𝗯𝗲𝗹𝗼𝗻𝗴𝘀 𝗶𝗻 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗱𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗵𝗶𝗽.
The companies that build the best experiences in 2025 will be the ones that 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗱 𝘄𝗶𝘁𝗵 𝗹𝗼𝘃𝗲, 𝗻𝗼𝘁 𝗳𝗲𝗮𝗿.

It’s easy to manage people. It’s hard to love them.
"Great leaders don’t focus on managing tasks. They focus on caring for people." —

But let me ask you this: 𝗪𝗼𝘂𝗹𝗱 𝗬𝗢𝗨 𝘄𝗮𝗻𝘁 𝘁𝗼 𝘄𝗼𝗿𝗸 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝘆𝗼𝘂?
Would YOU want to be your own customer?

If the answer is no, 𝗶𝘁’𝘀 𝘁𝗶𝗺𝗲 𝘁𝗼 𝘀𝘁𝗼𝗽 𝗺𝗮𝗻𝗮𝗴𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗿𝘁 𝗹𝗼𝘃𝗶𝗻𝗴.
Because love drives loyalty. 𝗟𝗼𝘃𝗲 𝗰𝗿𝗲𝗮𝘁𝗲𝘀 𝘁𝗿𝘂𝘀𝘁. 𝗟𝗼𝘃𝗲 𝗶𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗽𝗲𝘁𝗶𝘁𝗶𝘃𝗲 𝗮𝗱𝘃𝗮𝗻𝘁𝗮𝗴𝗲 𝗻𝗼 𝗼𝗻𝗲 𝗶𝘀 𝘁𝗮𝗹𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗮𝗯𝗼𝘂𝘁.

𝗖𝗮𝗹𝗹 𝘁𝗼 𝗔𝗰𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻:
Lead with love. 𝗜𝘁’𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗺𝗼𝘀𝘁 𝗱𝗶𝘀𝗿𝘂𝗽𝘁𝗶𝘃𝗲 𝘁𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗰𝗮𝗻 𝗱𝗼.

Your Experience Evangelist,

Video Credit: All rights belong to the respective owner. Please DM for credit or removal

comments.commentText: People feel when you are an authentic leader.

posts.name:
Nuwpur Jain
Nuwpur Jain
posts.content:
My dadi died 7 days back BUT she lived an absolutely full life which shocks me even today

Here's what made her extraordinary:

1) The Family Matriarch: She nurtured an incredible legacy of 51 hearts - 6 children, 18 grandchildren, and 27 great-grandchildren. Each one carrying a piece of her boundless love.

2) The Eternal Explorer: At 80+, she had the curiosity of a 21-year-old, traveling from Singapore to Dubai, and finally to Ram Mandir - living life with more enthusiasm than people a quarter her age.

3) The Graceful Goodbye: Seven days ago, she left us exactly how she lived - peacefully, having fulfilled all her wishes, and without suffering. A perfect ending to a life lived perfectly.

Here's to you, Dadi - forever young, forever loved ️

comments.commentText: Nuwpur, your tribute to your grandmother beautifully captures the essence of a remarkable life well-lived. Her legacy of love and curiosity is truly inspiring and serves as a reminder of how to embrace life fully, regardless of age. Thank you for sharing such heartfelt memories.
Priyank Ahuja Living proof that the best things in life come without an expiry date

Are slow-moving deals costing you more than just time?

The faster deals move through your pipeline, the sooner they close.

Hello, revenue and momentum.

Yes, you know this.

But are you LIVING it?

How confident are you that there are ZERO stalled opportunities inflating your pipeline, creating a false sense of progress, or hiding the real value in each stage.

Take a moment today to audit your pipe.

By consistently pushing deals forward, you uncover bottlenecks, prioritize qualified prospects, and maintain a healthy, actionable pipeline.

posts.name:
Artificial Intelligence, Deep Learning, Machine Learning
Artificial Intelligence, Deep Learning, Machine Learning
posts.content:
The assertion by Elon Musk that AI has “exhausted human knowledge” is a glaring fallacy. 

Human knowledge, ingenuity, and mystery stretch far beyond what AI can process, encapsulate, or replicate.

Consider the Great Pyramid of Giza, a marvel of engineering and precision that remains an enigma. Composed of 2,400,000 blocks, some weighing up to 70 tons, its precision—1 cm of error across the base and near-perfect alignment with cardinal points—is unmatched even with modern laser-guided systems. To meet the proposed timeline of 10 years, ancient builders would have placed one massive block every 60 seconds, for 10 hours a day, without fail—using tools no more advanced than copper.

AI, for all its advancements, cannot decode such mysteries. It is trained on datasets curated by humans, yet vast reservoirs of knowledge remain untapped: oral traditions, undocumented histories, and the untranscribed nuances of thousands of languages. AI’s limitations are evident in its hallucinations—outputs that lack factual grounding—and the reliance on synthetic data, where models essentially recycle their own interpretations, risking a loop of diminishing reliability.

Knowledge isn’t static. It is an evolving frontier defined by human curiosity, creativity, and the ability to grapple with the unknown. AI does not wonder, dream, or innovate; it learns patterns within the known. If the Great Pyramid, built 4,500 years ago, still defies comprehension, how could machines, bound by finite datasets, ever claim mastery over the vastness of human thought?

AI is a transformative tool, but it remains a mirror of human input—not a rival to human intellect. Let us not diminish humanity’s depth by calling it “exhausted.” Instead, let AI complement our endless pursuit of discovery, as we venture into realms it cannot yet fathom.

comments.commentText: Bit hypocritical to generate this post in ChatGPT, no?

Interesting viewpoint and to some degree i would agree with you. However your thesis still didn't disprove Mr. Musk's point since you yourself have pointed out that the pyramids represent 'lost' knowledge, i.e. no longer available to humanity much like NASA has 'forgotten' how to get to the moon and we are now relearning this knowledge.

Francis Joseph thank you for your thoughtful response. While I agree that some knowledge might appear ‘lost,’ I would argue it is often dormant rather than permanently gone. The knowledge behind the pyramids or NASA’s lunar feats was not eradicated—it evolved or was deprioritized as humanity’s needs shifted. AI, however, cannot ‘lose’ or ‘rediscover’ knowledge because it doesn’t possess agency, curiosity, or the iterative growth process unique to human ingenuity. Musk’s assertion fails to account for the expansive, regenerative capacity of human creativity, which goes far beyond simply relearning. The pyramids and space travel are powerful examples of humanity’s ability to transcend eras—not limits.
